snippet: Bo Xilai, once a rising star in the Communist Party, rejected accusations that he took bribes and called testimony from his wife “laughable” on the first day of his trial.
abstract: Bo Xilai, once a rising star in China's Communist Party, takes pugnacious stand in opening session of his corruption trial, rejecting accusations that he took bribes and ridiculing his wife's testimony against him; trial unfurls in unexpectedly open manner, as authorities allow running court microblog accessible by millions.

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
byline.contributor: Chris Buckley contributed reporting from Hong Kong. Patrick Zuo contributed research from Jinan, and Mia Li and Shi Da from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: Bo Xilai, once a rising star in the Communist Party, rejected accusations that he took bribes and called testimony from his wife “laughable” on the first day of his trial.

headline.main: As Surprisingly Open Trial Begins in China, Fallen Politician Shows Defiance
